We are looking for a volunteer who is: -Welcoming and friendly. -Collaborative, reliable, punctual, flexible. -Willing to commit each Saturday 10am to 1pm. We offer: - A valuable experience working in a cultural organization. - Free Spanish classes.
10029.title: Assistant Teacher For Kids Spanish Classes

10029.description: Job Description: As a Cooking Class Assistant for after-school classes, you will be a key player in creating the culinary experiences that shape the future generation of creative cooks and thoughtful eaters. Along the way, you’ll have the opportunity to engage with the local community of families, chefs, and restaurants that have partnered with usto give kids from all backgrounds the opportunity to cook and eat healthy meals. Your Role: We need enthusiastic, food-savvy volunteers who are ready and eager to jump into the kitchen and lead cooking classes with middle school aged girls from East Harlem. A love for working with kids and experimenting with new recipes is a must. You will be responsible for leading students through a culinary lesson plan, ensuring kids stay safe in the kitchen, and maintaining a fun, friendly, and educational cooking environment. Professional Growth: This is your chance to get hands-on in a school classroom as you take your passions for food, cooking, education to the next level. In addition to engaging with local communities of families and students, you will also be working with a top chef from the Harlem community. Sample Tasks: Assist After-School Cooking Classes for middle school girls, teaching basic knife skills, chopping techniques, and kitchen safety Supervise groups of up to twenty students during cooking classes Set up and clean up spaces in schools as part of prep for cooking events Skills and Requirements: Cooking experience and comfortability in the kitchen (formal culinary experience is not required) Past experience working with kids Organized, creative, and able to adapt to situations on the fly Passion for education, cooking, nutrition, and teaching kids
10029.title: Cooking Class Assistant

10029.description: DREAM, an award winning youth development program, is seeking volunteer tutors to provide academic support to our middle school after-school students in East Harlem and the South Bronx. Tutors work with youth individually and in small groups to help improve student success in class, increase subject-specific retention, and contribute to overall academic enrichment and development. What You’ll Do Support academic enrichment activities, including homework help and tutoring; Provide individualized and team-wide support all after-school program activities and initiatives; Serve as a role model and build positive relationships with youth; What We’re Looking For Strong command of one or more of the following academic subjects: English, Math, Science, and/or Social Studies Previous experience working with youth; Possess creativity, enthusiasm, initative, flexibility, and patience; Solid oral communication skills; Ability to make a consistent, weekly commitment; Bachelor’s Degree (a plus); 1-2 years previous tutoring experience (a major plus). Benefits Gain invaluable experience and opportunities for professional development at an award-winning youth development program; Receive an optional professional reference upon completion of your service term; Join an incredible community of passionate staff and volunteers. Minimum Commitment: 1-2 hours per week for a full cycle. Cycle 1: October - December/ Cycle 2: February - May. When: ******Monday - Thursday******* 4pm-5pm (time depends on tutor availability and program site assignment) DREAM provides equal opportunity for all volunteers.
10029.title: Volunteer as a Middle School Tutor

10029.description: Opus 118 Harlem School of Music ( www.Opus118.org) provides high-quality music instruction in an environment that nurtures excellence and creativity. Students in the East Harlem community are served with tuition-free twice-weekly group violin instruction during regular school hours and subsidized private instruction for violin, viola, cello, guitar, and piano after school hours. Opus 118 Harlem School of Music was founded by the now-legendary Roberta Guaspari, whose fight for in-school music programs in East Harlem became the subject of a documentary ( Small Wonders) and a feature film (Music from the Heart). Roberta continues to work in East Harlem Schools while actively training the next generation of teachers for Opus 118. Opus 118’s partnership with Kaufman Music Center ( www.kaufmanmusiccenter.org) has led to an exciting growth period, and we are currently interviewing qualified individuals to intern with us for the 2018-2019 school year, helping with administrative duties and assisting both teachers and students. This is an opportunity for those interested in arts administration to get hands-on experience in multiple facets of a non-profit organization. Department: Arts Administration Reports to: Director of Programs and Development Schedule: 12 hours per week, 3-6pm M-Th. Preference given to candidates who can commit to full 30 week calendar. Duties Required: serve as contact for parents of enrolled students at one After-School Program site receive and process student registrations enroll students in classes/lessons observe lesson schedule and notify parents/faculty of confirmed times and cancellations maintain accurate records of student attendance process tuition payments manage classroom scheduling and set-up assist with program-related publications, web-content, and social media prepare program enrollment and activity reports as needed additional responsibilities to be determined as needed, including performance management and organizational projects Requirements for the Position A passion for music education and working with young people Self-starting, organized, methodical Ability to work under pressure, multi-task, have outstanding interpersonal and communication skills A desire to learn about arts administration and the different tasks found within a non-profit environment An enthusiasm for learning and a willingness to take on a variety of tasks
10029.title: Non-Profit Music Organization Volunteer

10029.description: This is a wonderful opportunity to support school staff and elementary school students during lunchtime and recess from 10:30-11:30 am. Students eat in cafeteria from 10:30-11:00 am then go out to the school yard to play from 11-11:30 am. We are looking persons who can supervise students at the lunch table then lead them to the yard and facilitate organized play. We think of organized play broadly so it can include any sports, team building games, dance, art or any other. We will supply any equipment needed. This opportunity is for the entire school year but we are looking to place a few volunteers so if you can not commit to the full school year please let us know how many months you can commit to.
10029.title: Facilitate Elementary School Organized Play (Lunchtime)
10029.org: Ps 108 Assemblyman Angelo Del Toro Educational Com

For over 40 years, Union Settlement has provided Meals on Wheels to East Harlem's older residents that are often economically struggling and living alone. Our Meals on Wheels program currently serves approximately 450 homebound seniors each day. When: Any day from Monday through Friday 9am - 11am. Volunteers may choose the frequency of their commitment. Those under 21 must be accompanied by a legal guardian.

10029.description: Union Settlement - Senior Services is seeking a volunteer to facilitate a Beginner ESL class to improve members Basic English skills. The participants of this class will be senior citizens whose native language is Spanish. We would like a volunteer to come in once or twice a week for about an hour or two, although days and hours are based on volunteer’s flexibility. The volunteer must be available during normal business hours Monday through Friday between the hours of 9am to 4pm. Responsibilities Experience teaching is preferred. Must be able to plan and create program agenda Preparation of handouts and lesson plans Volunteer must be reliable, and dedicated to the position. Must be comfortable teaching and working with senior citizens. Group of about 5-10 seniors Requirements Volunteer must have good communication skills. We are looking for someone to be creative, and open minded. A person that can have patience, energy, and problem solving skills to help seniors learn English. If you think this is the volunteer position for you please respond to this posting! Please send contact information and resume to Jeanette Iturbides Jiturbides@unionsettlement.org
10029.title: ESL Volunteer for Spanish Speaking Senior Citizens

10029.description: We are looking for somebody who has experience with grant writing and application. Qualifications needed for position: Strong writing skills with a successful track record of securing grant funding. Location for work: Can be done from home; office is available if preferred. Time commitment required: Flexible, as available We offer: Free Spanish classes. About us: We are a 39-year-old community bases non profit arts and education institution in New York City. From Spanish classes, to concerts, art exhibits, poetry nights, salsa classes and more. We are sure to have a little something here for everyone.
10029.title: Grant Writer

10029.description: We are looking for aspiring or qualified ESL teachers to work with our wonderful non-profit organization. We teach immigrant women on Fridays and Saturdays at a Community School in East Harlem. The school has donated the space for us, and many of the women are parents of their students. The majority of the students are literacy level. They are learning their ABCs and slowly learn vocabulary and very simple sentences. Others are more advanced and can discuss situations and issues. Non training is necessary, as we will happily give support and training throughout. You must have a genuine desire to help immigrants thrive in their new country. We are looking to add teachers to our rotation schedule for two mornings a month. Class times are 9:30-11:30 Friday and Saturday. There is no compensation, we are all 100% volunteers at our organization, but we are a fun group, enjoy our work and are building a real community group.
10029.title: ESL Assistant

10029.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning. The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Session times are flexible: (Monday to Thursday, with volunteer times between 9 and 5). Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10029.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 38 Roberto Clemente, NYC)

10029.description: The Carter Burden Network is dedicated to supporting the efforts of older people to remain in their homes living independently, safely, and with dignity. Volunteers are an integral component of the Carter Burden Network's 40+ years of success. No matter your age, experience or schedule, CBN can accommodate your needs to ensure that you have a meaningful and effective volunteer experience. Carter Burden/Leonard Covello Senior Program is looking for a volunteer to maintain the safety and wellbeing of center members using the fitness facility. The areas of responsibility include, but are not limited to: Oversee gym during proposed hours Keep gym area neat and clutter free Make sure all members sign in We are looking for someone fun, energetic and reliable. Qualifications: Minimum Degree: High School Diploma CPR/AED certification preferred Certified fitness instructor preferred, but not necessary Experience working with older adults preferred, but not necessary Schedule: Flexible Please send your resume to Volunteer@carterburdennetwork.org
10029.title: Gym Attendant Needed! Help Seniors Stay Safe & Fit!

10029.description: URGENT! We need Classroom Aide Volunteers for our Early Childhood Socialization groups, starting October 15th. Volunteer aides help support the mom/toddler interaction in a cheerful, interactive classroom setting. We have approximately 10 - 15 moms/toddlers (15 months - 3 years of age) per class. Focus of the program is supporting the development and socialization needs of the child, and support the bonding between parent and child, so that the child can achieve the milestones for development. Includes art and music activities as well as free play in the classroom to support the learning needs of the child and fosters bonding between parent and child. Hours needed: 2 sessions a day available between Monday and Thursdays. Ideally a volunteer will commit to two days a week: Mondays and Wednesdays, 9:30 - 11:30 and 12:30 - 2:30 or Tuesdays and Thursdays from 9:30 - 11:30 and 12:30 - 2:30 pm. Bilingual (English and Spanish) helpful, but not necessary. Must enjoy interacting with toddlers, and have an interest in early childhood development.
10029.title: URGENT! We need Classrooms Aides for our Early Childhood Socialization Program

10029.description: Go the extra mile with Back on My Feet NYC's Team Bowery North! Dedicated teams of volunteers run 2-4 miles with our members who are transitioning out of homelessness. We encourage runners of all speeds to become a part of our community! Team Bowery North meets at 315 E 115th St. every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 5:45-6:45AM. To find out more and sign up for an orientation, visit https://www.backonmyfeet.org/get-involved/volunteer/
10029.title: East Harlem Morning Runner

10029.description: East Harlem Tutorial Program offers a variety of volunteer opportunities through our public charter schools, after-school, and summer programs. The programs range from subject-matter tutoring, providing students with homework help, mentoring, and preparing high school students for college success. Volunteers support our scholars, prepare them for academic success, encourage their social enrichment, and help them gain the confidence they will need to succeed in college and in life. Check out our volunteer options below: Out of School Time (OST) Programs Classroom Buddies - Volunteers work in one of our Kindergarten through 5th Grade after-school classes assisting our scholars with homework, walking them through engaging classroom activities, and supporting our Assistant and Lead Teachers. Commitment : Twice a week When : Monday through Thursday, 4 p.m. - 6 p.m. Elementary Homework Help - Volunteers support our young scholars as they tackle tough homework while building supportive relationships and positively impacting their academic achievement. In small groups, volunteers address the individual needs of our scholars and focus on content they are learning during the week. Commitment : Once a week When : Saturdays, 10 a.m. - 11:30 a.m. (Oct - Jan only) Road to Success - Middle School years are some of the most formative for any student. This time will determine which high school they get into, which will ultimately be a key factor in whether they go to college. Road to Success provides a small group setting where scholars receive homework help from volunteers interested in making a difference in the lives of young people. Commitment : Once a week When : Monday through Thursday, 5 p.m. - 6 p.m. Circle Up Tutoring (formerly known as University Tutoring) - Volunteers help our middle and high school scholars succeed in various subjects (Math, English, Science, History), while in a one-on-one setting. Volunteers should feel confident tutoring and demonstrate success in a 6th - 12th grade level subject. Commitment : Once a week When : Monday and Thursday, 6:30 p.m. - 8 p.m. East Harlem Scholars Academies Scholars After School Clubs - Do you enjoy soccer, flag football, dance or fencing? Are you a homework whiz? Come support our elementary and middle school scholars, engaging them in fun clubs geared towards being active and expressing themselves creatively! Volunteers can choose which club, sport, or activity to participate in. CLASSROOM/TEACHING AIDE Provide logistical support: signing in students, submitting attendance to program director, handing out snack, and other tasks as needed Classroom management support: assisting students with small group work/projects, ensuring materials are available for all students, implement strategies created by in-classroom teacher, etc. Aid after school staff with student dismissal and sign out SPORTS AIDE (Experience in sports related activities a plus!) Provide logistical support: signing in students, submitting attendance to program director, handing out snack, and other tasks as needed Aid coaches with practices, including: drills, running plays, stretches, and one on one assistance for students. Aid after school staff with student dismissal and sign out Commitment : Once a week When : Monday through Thursday, 4 p.m. - 5:30 p.m.; Fridays, 12:45 p.m. - 5:30 p.m. Lunch & Playground Pals Support with preparing elementary student lunches and providing general lunchroom support including escorting scholars between lunchroom and bathrooms, as well as lunchroom clean up Engage with elementary school scholars at tables in friendly conversations and help create a positive lunchroom culture Support recess time by providing a structured activities such as basketball, tag, or relay races (volunteer suggestions are always welcomed!) In addition to the responsibilities above, volunteers support with early dismissal and running an enrichment club in the late pick-up room on Fridays Commitment : Once a week When : Mondays - Thursdays,10 a.m. - 12 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. - 2 p.m. Reading Buddies Support during after school reading clubs in structured reading comprehension skill building activities Volunteers work through activities with their assigned elementary scholar weekly under the supervision of a reading specialist Commitment : Once a week When : Mondays - Thursdays, 4 p.m. - 5:30 p.m. Saturday Academy - Volunteer support in elementary and middle school classrooms during teacher-led ELA and Math test prep in small group activities for students that need extra support. Commitment : Once a week When : Saturdays, 8:30 a.m. - 12:30 p.m. All prospective volunteers must apply using the online application: http://bttr.im/ubhw2
10029.title: Volunteer with East Harlem Tutorial Program as a tutor, mentor, and friend for our scholars!

10029.description: As we are currently facing very difficult budget cuts in New York State, our Food Pantry which serves East Harlem children and families is experiencing a dramatic reduction of donations. Our shelves are barely stocked. If you work for an organization that might be interested in hosting a Food Drive, please be in touch (646) 672-0434. Canned food, dry goods, and other practical foodstuffs are most needed. We can pick up at any site in New York City. Thank you for remembering our most vulnerable New Yorkers!!
10029.title: Can Your Organization host a Food Drive for our Food Pantry?

10029.description: STARTING IN OCTOBER 2018: Help us help the neediest students in New York City! ! We need caring, committed after school Tutors for our After School Tutoring Program for children in K - 3. Times needed: MONDAYS AND WEDNESDAYS FROM 3:30 - 4:30. Tutors ideally commit to two days a week if possible as you would tutor the same child twice a week. You will tutor one-on-one a child in grades K- 3 who struggles with reading and writing at grade level. Most of the children are children of immigrants and English is not spoken at home, so they struggle with English reading and writing at school. Tutoring begins mid October and continues through the spring semester (until June 2018). Please help an East Harlem child! Tutoring makes all the difference for our children -- the difference between success and failure in school. If you would like to volunteer, please email an inquiry email with your resume to tgough@lsafhs.org
10029.title: URGENT!!  We Need Tutors to Tutor East Harlem Children Mondays and Wednesdays!

10029.description: Yes summer is here but the new school year is just around the corner! Children in our LSA programs will need back to school supplies. Do you know that it costs approximately 85.00 per child to supply a school aged child with back to s school supplies? Our East Harlem parents struggle to get their children all they need to be successful in the new school year and you can help. Help us give essential back to school suppies for children in our after school tutoring and home work help programs. Please see link here: https://yougivegoods.com/lsa-schoolsupplydrive-2018 Here are other ways your company can help: 1) Your company can host a Toy or Book Drive for children in our programs. We are always in need for educational toys and books for children ages 0 - 12. (we can pick up donations as needed). 2) Host a food drive for our food pantry - we always need pantry essentials, and we can pick up the donation. 3) Your company can work with children at our center for a \"team building\" activity - for example, a 1.5 hour arts and crafts activity or outdoor sports activity are just a couple of ways your group can connect with East Harlem children in our programs. Contact the Volunteer Director for more information. 3) Your company can sponsor a summer trip for our children (to NY state parks, beaches, the Bronx zoo, etc.). For more information about how your company can participate in an activity with our East Harlem children, please contact the Volunteer Director at LSA Family Health Service (646) 672-0434 or email at tgough@lsafhs.org.
10029.title: Corporate Sponsorship Needed!  Lean how your company can  help our East Harlem families!

10029.description: We need an Advocate for our Advocacy/Emergency Services program. Position requires a commitment for at least two full days, between Monday thru Friday 9 am - 5 pm. Advocate meets one-one one with clients by appointment, conducting intakes, assessing the client's needs, distributing food from the food pantry, and making referrals for necessary services. Duties also includes preparing food packages and stocking and maintaining the food pantry; educating clients regarding government benefits and entitlements; representing clients and advocating on their behalf at the city welfare center or at state hearings; making referrals for child care, counseling, legal assistance, job training, etc. Assist clients to identify and address underlying problems that bring families to the Adovcacy office. Training provided; a six month minimum commitment required. For more information, please contact the Volunteer Director at (646) 672-0434 or email tgough@lsafhs.org.
10029.title: URGENT!  Volunteer Advocate Needed for our Advocacy/Emergency Services Program

10029.description: If you like thrift shops, you'll love the Sharing Place thrift shop! The Sharing Place offers high quality goods at very low prices for members of the East Harlem community. We need help in sorting and pricing clothes, helping customers, helping to decorate/set up store. We also need a volunteer who can assist with administrative tasks; i.e. help with thank you letters to donors, or helping to organize special store sales for the community. We would love to have a volunteer who can commit to at least two or three days a week, flexible schedule. Hours are Mon - Sat 10 - 5. For more information, please see our website www.littlesistersfamily.org and click The Sharing Place Thrift Store
10029.title: URGENT! Thrift Shop Helpers Needed!

10026.description: Each Wednesday, we prep & serve a simple vegetarian meal offering in Central Harlem for anyone who needs a meal. One can help cook and/or serve and/or clean up. Time commitment is flexible: 2 & 1/2 hours to prep/cook, 1 hour to set up/serve, 1 hour clean up. One can help out with any part of the meal. Any level of skill is accepted.
10026.title: Volunteer To Cook & Serve Every Wednesday

10027.description: Volunteer with Behind the Book (www.behindthebook.org), a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to explore stories and empower their voices. Through our innovative programs, which are part of the class curricula, accomplished authors visit high-needs pre-K-12 classrooms to guide students in creating their own writing projects based on the theme of the author's book. You need no experience or training to volunteer. As a coach, you'll support and encourage students as they work on their projects. This research workshop needs your help in Harlem, NYC. To sign up, contact volunteer@behindthebook.org with the program code and date. We'll supply the address, directions, and other information when you're confirmed: Program RT45LT-MK Date/Time: Wednesday, December 5th / 4:30 - 6:00 PM Volunteer Role: Research Coach About the program: Fourth- and fifth-graders read selections from the book series I Survived... by Lauren Tarshis, which recount terrifying, real-life historical events as seen through the eyes of a kid who lived through them. Research coaches will help students find facts about another historical event, which they’ll write about from the perspective of someone who witnessed it. For information on other programs around the city, please visit http://www.behindthebook.org/current-volunteer-opportunities/ To join our team and receive announcements of new programs as they're scheduled, please complete our brief questionnaire at http://www.behindthebook.org/join-us/volunteer/
10027.title: Research coach for Harlem, NYC public school literacy program (RTlt)

10027.description: Volunteer with Behind the Book (www.behindthebook.org), a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to explore stories and empower their voices. Through our innovative programs, which are part of the class curricula, accomplished authors visit high-needs pre-K-12th grade classrooms to guide students in creating their own writing projects based on the theme of the author's book. You need no experience or training to volunteer. As a coach, you'll support and encourage students as they work on their projects. This writing workshop needs your help in Harlem, NYC. To sign up, reply with the program code to volunteer@behindthebook.org. We'll supply the address, directions, and other information when you're confirmed: Program 1544PK-L Date: Thursday, December 13th, 2018 Time: 9:00 - 10:30 AM Volunteer Role: Writing coach About the program: Third-graders read Drumbeat in Our Feetby Patricia Keeler to learn about African traditions that celebrate ancestral stories passed down through artifacts, music, and dance. Students will be introduced to African fabrics called kente, discover how they tell stories, and perform a play that incorporates both dance and kente. Coaches will guide small groups of students in editing essays about where their own families come from, and how traditions have been passed down. For information on other program dates around the city, please visit http://www.behindthebook.org/current-volunteer-opportunities/ To join our team and receive announcements of new programs as they're scheduled, please submit our brief questionnaire at http://www.behindthebook.org/join-us/volunteer/
10027.title: Writing coach for Harlem, NYC public school literacy program (154pk)

10027.description: Volunteer with Behind the Book (www.behindthebook.org), a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to explore stories and empower their voices. Through our innovative programs, which are part of the class curricula, accomplished authors visit high-needs pre-K-12th grade classrooms to guide students in creating their own writing projects based on the theme of the author's book. You need no experience or training to volunteer. As a coach, you'll support and encourage students as they work on their projects. This writing workshop needs your help at a school in Harlem, NYC. To sign up, reply with the program code to volunteer@behindthebook.org. We'll supply the address, directions, and other information when you're confirmed: Program 1544PK-L Date: Thursday, December 13th, 2018 Time: 9:00 - 10:30 AM Volunteer Role: Writing coach About the program: Third-graders who read \"Drumbeat in our Feet\" by Patricia Keeler are learning about African traditions that celebrate ancestral stories passed down through artifacts, music, and dance. Students will be introduced to African fabrics called kente, and discover how they tell stories. They’ll also perform a play about Queen Nzinga’s life that incorporates both dance and kente cloth. Coaches will support students in editing their writing about where their own families come from, and how traditions have been passed down. For information on other program dates around the city, please visit http://www.behindthebook.org/current-volunteer-opportunities/ To join our team and receive announcements of new programs as they're scheduled, please submit our brief questionnaire at http://www.behindthebook.org/join-us/volunteer/
10027.title: Writing coach for Harlem, NYC public school literacy program (154pk)

10027.description: HEAF is seeking dedicated individuals to serve as academic coaches to providing tutoring and support and/or to serve as Teacher’s Assistants for our High Expectations (Middle School) students, grades 6-8. About HEAF: The Harlem Educational Activities Fund, Inc. (HEAF) is a comprehensive not-for-profit supplemental education and youth development organization that supports and assists dedicated students to develop the intellectual curiosity, academic ability, social values and personal resiliency they need to ensure success in school, career and life. HEAF identifies scholars in middle school and supports them until they are successfully admitted to four-year colleges through a variety of after-school, Saturday and summer programs. Purpose: Academic Tutors ensure that are students have the academic and study skills needed to succeed in middle, high school, and college. As a college bound program, HEAF’s goal is for 100% of our scholars to graduate from both high school and a four year college. To ensure all HEAF scholars realize this goal, HEAF mandates tutoring and Academic Success Programs for scholars who fall below HEAF’S minimum academic standards of 80% and above in all core class. Tutors provide assistance to students in the four core subject areas: Math, English/ELA, Science, and Social Studies and are matched with students based on the coach’s skills in specific subject areas and the student’s needs. Responsibilities: Assess and assist students with homework and test preparation in at least one of the core subjects: Math, English Language Arts (ELA), Science, and Social Studies - see below for more details about concepts covered in each subject area Evaluate and record student progress after each session Attend and participate in scheduled tutor orientation & training meetings Communicate academic progress to program staff Create a rich learning environment that aids in instructing students with various learning styles Complete and submit required documentation, including hours log Qualifications: Bachelor’s degree preferred - some college required. (Masters students in Education encouraged to apply) Advanced skills in Mathematics, English Language Arts, Science, and/or Social Studies Experience tutoring middle school students Strong work ethic and interpersonal skills Willingness to promote HEAF educational and youth development philosophy. Ability to work collaboratively with others Bilingual (Spanish/English) candidates are highly encouraged to apply. Time Commitment: Academic Tutors are asked to make a minimum of a one hour/week commitment for a minimum of one semester. HEAF’s High Expectations tutoring program operates on Saturdays from 2:30-3:30pm . Support: Orientation will be provided for all tutors at the beginning of the Fall term. Additionally, tutors are given access to a folder of resources that can be used during their sessions. Optional training sessions are offered for our program team throughout the Fall term. Benefits Build one-on-one relationships with students, while instilling confidence in themselves and their academic abilities Work as part of a collaborative and innovative team Receive ongoing training opportunities Ensure our students have the skills necessary to successfully accomplish their academic goals This position is an unpaid, volunteer position that reports to the Program Coordinator for High Expectations, and is also supported by the Volunteer Engagement Coordinator.
10027.title: Middle School Academic Tutor

10027.description: Market Access Program Intern Start Small Think Big (Start Small) is a not-for-profit organization located in Harlem. Our mission is to help under resourced individuals build and sustain thriving businesses in order to increase their personal financial security and stimulate economic activity in underserved communities in New York City. We believe that entrepreneurship results in increased innovation and sustained economic growth for everyone, in particular, those most traditionally marginalized. The Market Access Program Intern will work with the Marketing Program Manager to assist our entrepreneurs with marketing and sales business needs. This includes developing resource guides, learning more about sales opportunities in NYC and online, and supporting our communications team with a social media strategy. Job Responsibilities shall include, but are not limited to: Assist in managing Start Small Think Big social media platforms, including creating and posting content, identifying influencers in the space, and responding to comments and questions received from entrepreneurs. Research and develop informative resource guides focused on assisting entrepreneurs in identifying and addressing business challenges and community resources necessary to increase business success. Support the Marketing Program Manager in delivering services, via workshops, consultations, and project-based relationships, this includes managing logistics of events, coordinating entrepreneur attendance, and all necessary follow-up calls. Assist in developing the evaluation rubrics used by volunteer marketing experts to help entrepreneurs identify weaknesses in their current marketing practices. Preferred Skills/Qualifications: Current undergraduate student with strong interest in writing, social media, and communications, nonprofit program management, or other related disciplines. High level of computer proficiency including familiarity with Google Applications, social media (Facebook, Instagram and Twitter) and MS Office. Knowledge of programs: Buffer and Canva a plus. Demonstrated commitment to inclusive community/economic development, social and economic justice work, and/or anti-poverty work. Excellent verbal and written communication skills, time management, and interpersonal skills; Highly organized, creative and self-motivated; a strong problem-solver and analytical/critical thinker; and Experience working in low-income and/or immigrant communities. TO APPLY: Submit resume to: Eliza Edge, Market Access Program Manager at eliza@startsmallthinkbig.org (include subject line: \"[your name] Market Access Program Intern.\" This position is unpaid, but may be used for course credit where appropriate. Minimum of 20 hours/week at our office. Days are flexible. Start Small Think Big is an equal opportunity employer with a standing policy of nondiscrimination. This means that all qualified persons are accorded an equal opportunity for employment or promotion without regard to actual or perceived race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, disability, medical condition, marital status, sex, age, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, family responsibility, personal appearance, genetic information, matriculation, or political affiliation.
10027.title: Marketing Program Assistant (Internship)

10027.description: The Admissions team at HEAF is responsible for developing, planning, implementing and managing HEAFs Outreach and Admissions strategy, recruiting HEAF scholars for each of HEAF’s classes, and engaging and building relationships with external champions, including schools, NYCHA, and faith-based organizations. The Admissions Program assistant supports the Manager of Admissions and Community Relations with outreach, communications and data entry to ensure that we are achieving our admissions strategy and recruiting high-quality applicants. Location: HEAF Harlem Site - 2090 Adam Clayton Powell, Jr. Blvd, 10 th Floor, New York, NY 10027 Responsibilities: Conduct phone calls to potential HEAF families (bi-lingual candidates preferred) Assist with putting together materials and mailings to send to potential families and schools Collect and maintain student information, including application and other supplemental materials (such as report cards) Record data entry for admissions applications and supporting documents Qualifications: Motivated self-starter and team player with strong interpersonal and communication skills, both oral and written, and a positive attitude. Experience with database management and analysis Ability to set clear goals and follow through with flexible and creative problem solving. Conceptual ability for the larger perspective with a strong attention to detail and ability to multitask. Working knowledge of computer and internet-based programs for use in communication, data entry and research. (e.g. using Microsoft Software (Word, Excel, and PowerPoint) Ability to converse and write in English and Spanish preferred Time Commitment: Volunteer’s weekly hours range from 5-10 hours per week depending on designated weekly work levels. The specific schedule is flexible and will be arranged with Manager of Admissions and Community Outreach Support: Orientation and training will be provided to the Program Assistant. Additionally, regular weekly check-ins will take place with the Manager of Admissions and Community Relations Benefits Provide critical support to the Admissions department Help ensure that the new class of HEAF students and their families are prepared and equipped with the knowledge and information needed to be successful at HEAF Learn about the internal processes and operations of a non-profit organization Expand your professional network through opportunities to connect with HEAF staff and supporters Be a member of a lively, dedicated, caring, and passionate team This position is an unpaid, volunteer position that reports to the Manager of Admissions and Community Relations.
10027.title: Admissions Program Assistant

10027.description: The Youth Development Program Assistant will support the Youth Development staff with the coordination and implementation of a quality program that enriches our HEAF students academically, socially, and emotionally. Responsibilities: Create a system for tracking student attendance and data Assist with organizing program documents and student files Implement a structure for collecting student information and ensuring student files are accurate and updated on a regular basis Input data from program documents into Salesforce, our online database Support with logistics and operations for the Youth Development department Place follow-up calls with students and families as directed Qualifications: Strong organizational skills and attention-to-detail Strong interpersonal skills, work ethic and professional values Able to work in a fast-paced environment Willingness to promote HEAF educational and youth development philosophy. Ability to work collaboratively with the HEAF staff Confident with MS office (Word, Excel, and PowerPoint) and comfortable learning new systems Time Commitment: The HEAF program operates from 11:00am-7:00pm Monday through Friday. The time commitment for this position is 10-20 hours a week. Specific schedule is flexible and will be arranged with the Associate Director. Support: Orientation and training will be provided to the Program Assistant. Additionally, regular weekly check-ins will take place with the Associate Director of Youth Development Benefits Gain valuable hands-on experience in the non-profit sector Contribute to the coordination of a successful program that deeply impacts the lives of students and the community Work as part of a collaborative and innovative team to provide opportunities to HEAF students
10027.title: Youth Development Program Assistant

10027.description: Hello! We are looking for a professional engineer (PE) to help our new project to establish an educational training center in Harlem for youth and for the wider community. We would like the advice of a State-licensed engineer as we develop our training space. We are looking for technical expertise. Thank you.
10027.title: Professional Engineer (PE)

10027.description: ATTENTION PHOTOGRAPHERS: Under-resourced small business owners are in need of high-resolution images of their products including food and retail products. The images are crucial for the businesses to have on their websites and social media pages. Start Small Think Big is seeking enthusiastic and reliable photographers who are interested in volunteering their skills to help underserved small business entrepreneurs build and sustain their thriving businesses. You must have a passion for all aspects of photography, but an individual with a specific interest in food and product photography would be ideal. Contact Eliza Edge, Market Access Program Manager for further details: eliza@startsmallthinkbig.org or visit bit.ly/startsmallthinkbig for this and other volunteer opportunities.
10027.title: Product Photography for Under-Resourced Small Businesses

10027.description: Researchers at Teachers College, Columbia University are seeking families with adolescents between the ages of 11-15 with a history of self-harm to participate in a study aimed at understanding adolescent behavior, parenting and family relationships. Participation in this study includes: Two in-person visits involving surveys and videotaped interviews (3 hours total) A one month follow up online survey/phone call (35-40 minutes) For more information about the study, watch our video: https://vimeo.com/244123769?ref=tw-share If you are interested in participating, please fill out the survey: http://www.tc.columbia.edu/child-and-adolescent-mental-health-project/get-involved/participate/ Questions? Call us at 212-678-8114 or email: CAMHP@tc.columbia.edu This is TC approved protocol #17-415.
10027.title: Seeking Parents and Teens for Research Study

10027.description: Are you a graphic designer looking to use your skills for greater good? Become a volunteer at Start Small Think Big! We are a non-profit that provides high quality legal, financial, and marketing assistance to low-to-moderate income entrepreneurs in NYC and San Francisco. We are looking for graphic designers interested in donating their time to assist entrepreneurs in: - Logo Design - Website Design - Printed Collateral Design - Promotional Material Design - Social Media Promotion - Website Audits Please join us in our effort to help our most vulnerable entrepreneurs succeed in one of the most challenging environments - roughly 50% of small business start-ups fail.
10027.title: Website Designers for Small Businesses

10027.description: DESCRIPTION Start Small Think Big (Start Small) is a not-for-profit organization located in Harlem. Our mission is to help low- to moderate-income individuals build and sustain thriving businesses in order to increase their personal financial security and stimulate economic activity in underserved communities in New York City and the Bay Area. We believe that entrepreneurship results in increased innovation and sustained economic growth for everyone, in particular, those most traditionally marginalized. The Marketing and Event Coordination Internship will work with the Market Access Program Director in assisting small business entrepreneurs in identifying and exploring new and varied sales opportunities for their business. The position will play a key role in helping Start Small Think Big develop community partnerships and formalizing a marketing strategy for sales opportunities, this includes but is not limited to, learning more about the various local sales opportunities available in NYC and the Bay Area and managing the communication and marketing of these opportunities to our community of entrepreneurs. Job Responsibilities shall include, but are not limited to: Manage weekly \"Tasting Thursdays\" at our office, which includes identifying new participants for sales opportunity, coordinating logistics with entrepreneurs prior to and during their scheduled tasting, and recording sales data after each opportunity. Write, produce, and help manage content to feature on SSTB Sales Alert emails, which feature key free, discounted, and paid opportunities available in their communities. Research and develop a database of all seasonal and year-round opportunities available in NYC and Bay Area. Develop resource guide on topics of interest for our entrepreneurs, as it relates to their marketing challenges, including but not limited to, web design resources, how to optimize sales, and strategies for successful social media use. Collaborate with Program Director to contact each retail opportunity to see whether a partnership is possible and if our entrepreneurs could tap into free and discounted vendor space. Coordinate all logistics related to featuring Start Small Businesses in retail opportunities with local street markets, fairs, and stores. Preferred Skills/Qualifications: Current undergraduate student with strong interest in writing, social media, and communications, nonprofit program management, or other related disciplines. High level of computer proficiency including familiarity with Google Applications, social media (Facebook and Instagram) and MS Office. Demonstrated commitment to inclusive community/economic development, social and economic justice work, and/or anti-poverty work; Excellent verbal and written communication skills, time management, and interpersonal skills; Highly organized, detail-oriented, creative and self-motivated; a strong problem-solver and critical thinker; and Experience working in low-income and/or immigrant communities. Start Small Think Big is an equal opportunity employer with a standing policy of nondiscrimination. This means that all qualified persons are accorded an equal opportunity for employment or promotion without regard to actual or perceived race, religion, color, national origin, ancestry, disability, medical condition, marital status, sex, age, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, family responsibility, personal appearance, genetic information, matriculation, or political affiliation. HOW TO APPLY mabell@startsmallthinkbig.org Submit resume or LinkedIn profile to: Mabell Fernandez, Market Access Program Director at mabell@startsmallthinkbig.org (include subject line: \"[your name] Marketing and Event Coordination Internship\"
10027.title: Marketing and Event Management Volunteer

10027.description: Located in Harlem on 132nd Street, Cecil Ivory House is a 24 bed transitional housing program targeting formerly homeless clients who are either mentally ill or dually diagnosed as mentally ill and chemically addicted. The mission of this program is to provide a safe and supportive environment where residents take part in rehabilitation interventions that will assist them in the attainment of their work, social and community living goals. A variety of services are available, including case management, substance abuse groups, medication monitoring, daily skills training and recreational activities. Now is your chance to step up and help us in our goals! Do you enjoy socializing, running game nights, showing movies or turning the stereo up a bit for a little dancing? Are you able to introduce yourself, share a few jokes, spread some smiles and host a small party? If so, the residents of Cecil Ivory would love to have you host a small Friday Night Social. We’ll provide the games, snacks and music; you just need to bring the smiles and good times! We are looking to start this up at 6:30pm and make it a bi-weekly event. So put on your party shirt and give me a call! PLEASE NOTE: In order to insure the integrity of the BRC volunteer program, as well as the well being of the clients we service, all interested parties must complete a New Volunteer Registration form and attend an orientation, prior to receiving an assignment. Apologies, but we are unable to accept walk-ins.
10027.title: Calling All Party Planners and Hosts!

10027.description: CALLING ALL MARKETING & ADVERTISING EXPERTS! Do you want to use your expertise to help underserved entrepreneurs build and sustain their thriving businesses? Our Market Access Program pairs entrepreneurs with pro bono marketing and advertising experts like you for project-based mentoring opportunities that address key Marketing challenges including: - Developing a strategic plan to improve business exposure over next three years. - Outlining appropriate social media channels, including goals and metrics for success. - Formalizing an online marketing plan with measurable goals for improving visibility and generating new customers. - Reviewing current branding strategy and its implementation. - Receiving detailed feedback on current website’s layout, user functionality, visual design, and content. - Thinking through a plan for maximizing business sales and outlining measurable goals. - Developing SEM plan with goals and strategy for improving website ranking. Please visit us at www.startsmallthinkbig.org to learn more about our organization and to see some of the businesses we serve. If you are interested in this opportunity and would like more information, please submit a volunteer interest form at bit.ly/startsmallthinkbig or book a 30 minute introductory call at bit.ly/sstbvolunteer. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to email Mabell Fernandez, Market Access Program Director at mabell@startsmallthinkbig.org We look forward to working with you!
10027.title: Strategic Marketing Plan Expert for Small Business

If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to email Mabell Fernandez, Market Access Program Director at mabell@startsmallthinkbig.org We look forward to working with you!
10027.title: Social Media Strategy Expert for Small Business

Our Market Access Program pairs entrepreneurs with pro bono marketing and advertising experts like you for project-based mentoring opportunities that address key Marketing challenges including: - Developing a strategic plan to improve business exposure over next three years. - Outlining appropriate social media channels, including goals and metrics for success. - Formalizing an online marketing plan with measurable goals for improving visibility and generating new customers. - Reviewing current branding strategy and its implementation. - Receiving detailed feedback on current website’s layout, user functionality, visual design, and content. - Thinking through a plan for maximizing business sales and outlining measurable goals. - Developing SEM plan with goals and strategy for improving website ranking. You must have a passion for all aspects of photography, but an individual with a specific interest in food and product photography would be ideal.
